detail.content: ********************************************** Configuring email client for NYU Home **********************************************  The basic reference is the following URL.  http://www.nyu.edu/its/email/configure/  ********************************************** Enabling SSL for incoming mail  mail.nyu.edu **********************************************  With regard to SSL, do not let your GUI confuse you between two different servers: SSL for mail.nyu.edu and SSL/TLS for smtp.nyu.edu.  Enabling SSL to encrypt incoming email messages. This affects the incoming mail server mail.nyu.edu.   http://www.nyu.edu/its/email/ssl/   For Apple Mail, the steps are simply the following.  - Click on SSL using port 993.  - Authentication: select Password.  - Relaunch Mail.   For Thunderbird,   - Click on SSL under Server Settings (not the Outgoing Server).   - Relaunch Thunderbird.  ********************************************** Authenticated SMTP (outgoing mail)  smtp.nyu.edu **********************************************  This allows you to send email from any location by authenticating  with the NYU SMTP server smtp.nyu.edu. The support for this is  unofficial but should work.  Apple Mail  Mail > Preferences > Accounts  Select the NYU Home account and click on Server settings  for smtp.nyu.edu.  - Server port: 587  - click on Use SSL  - Authentication via Password  - Fill out your username and pw for NYU Home.  Thunderbird  Ditto except you should click on TLS (instead of SSL).  iPhone (unverified)  In Settings > Mail for the outgoing mail server, put    smtp.nyu.edu:587  And under Advanced make sure that SSL is selected on for  the outgoing mail server.

NYU Mobile is NYU's official app for iOS and Android devices, offering real-time      shuttle tracking, university events, campus map, contact information from the NYU      Directory, University news, and more. For additional information and instructions on downloading     the app, visit www.nyu.edu/mobile .      Should you have any questions or concerns, please contact the IT Service Desk .                     These instructions will help you activate your BlackBerry or iPhone and connect to a variety of NYU services. Because instructions can vary from device to device and among wireless carriers, it's important that you rely on the product- and carrier-specific instructions that come with your phone.     While it is possible to use a variety of smart phones to access NYU resources, ITS' mobile support is currently limited. If you own a different brand, it may be possible to use portions of these instructions to configure your phone (details will vary). Check back for additional support in the future.    iOS devices (iPhone, iPod, iPad)   See the ServiceLink knowledge base for instructions:    Activating your iPhone   Configuring wired data synchronization for your iPhone   Managing your network and wireless connection on your iOS device   NYU Email / Calendar: Setting up an iOS device (iPhone, iPod, iPad)   Connect your iPhone, iPad or or iPod Touch to NYURoam Wireless     Browse all iOS-related knowledge base articles »    Blackberry   See the ServiceLink knowledge base for instructions:    NYU Email / Calendar: Setting up a BlackBerry phone (OS 10)   NYU Email / Calendar: Setting up a BlackBerry phone (OS 9 and below)   NYURoam/Wireless: Configuring a BlackBerry to connect to the 'nyu' network     Browse all BlackBerry-related knowledge base articles »      Android   See the ServiceLink knowledge base for instructions, including:    NYU Email / Calendar: Setting up an Android device   Wireless/NYURoam: Configuring an Android device to connect to the 'nyu' network     Browse all Android-related knowledge base articles »       Page last reviewed: May 30, 2014

If you're looking for the NYU Libraries EZProxy service, please contact the Libraries instead.        This legacy NYU-NET Proxy is being prepared for retirement; if possible, we encourage you to begin using VPN instead.                                        Important Note VPN is the best way to securely connect to NYU services from off campus. Unless you are sure that you need to use NYU-NET Proxy to connect to a certain resource, try using the NYU VPN service first.     NYU-NET Proxy helps you authenticate yourself as an NYU community member when you are connecting to certain    NYU resources from outside of NYU-NET. Using NYU-NET Proxy, your browser will employ a computer system here at    the University to help it access your remote destination (see the bottom of this page for more information about    proxy servers . When accessing NYU-NET in this way, you will be asked to type in your NYU NetID and password    (which is the same as your password for NYUHome). More About Proxy Servers   A proxy server is a server that sits between a client application, such as a web browser, and a remote server. The proxy server  intercepts each request to the remote server to see if it can fulfill the request itself. If not, it forwards the request to the  remote server. When a proxy server receives a request for an Internet service, such as a web page, if the request passes the  filtering requirements, the proxy server first looks in its local cache of previously downloaded web pages. If it finds the page,  it returns it to the person who requested it without needing to forward the request to the Internet. If it does not find the page, the  proxy server acts on behalf of the person and uses its own IP address to request the web page from the Internet.    An advantage of using a proxy server is that it can improve overall response time, since frequently-requested Internet sites are  likely to be in the proxy's cache.
